review.title: Towards a theory of granular sets
review.abstract: Motivated by the application problem of sensor fusion the author introduced the concept of graded set. It is reasoned that in classification problem arising in an information system (represented by information table), a novel set called Granular set naturally arises. It is realized that in any hierarchical classification problem, Granular set naturally arises. Also when the target set of objects forms a graded set the lower and upper approximations of target sets form a graded set. This generalizes the concept of rough set. It is hoped that a detailed theory of granular/ graded sets finds several applications.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION:
sections.text: Set theory as a branch of human endeavors was developed by the efforts of many mathematicians [Kam]. Such a theory found many applications in science, technology and other fields. In an effort to capture uncertainties in human thinking, Zadeh formulated and studied the theory of fuzzy sets. The theory of fuzzy sets found application in many areas of science and technology. Pawlak, a computer scientist, proposed and studied the concept of coarse set in an effort to capture other aspects of uncertainty that occur in applications such as database design. The theory of coarse sets supplemented the theory of fuzzy sets. In his research efforts related to the fusion problem in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN), the author discovered the idea of "graduated set" (discussed in Section 2) as a generalization of the idea of coarse set. In understanding the details of coarse set theory, the idea of "granular sets" is observed as biological sets: in biological systems biomicroscopic parts are observed as closely as in systems microscopic resolution.

sections.heading: 3. Granular Sets: Information System:
sections.text: In this section we will present the concept of the "granular set" and discuss how such a set naturally arises from the extraction of information from an information system. sections.heading: 4. Granular Sets : Applications:
sections.text: As previously discussed, granular sets naturally arise in different hierarchical classification problems that occur in different applications. Specifically, we have recognized that granular sets arise in classification problems associated with an information system represented by an information table. In this case, the sets arise when the target set is the entirety of the objects / patterns in X and the collection of feature sets forms a tiered set. The granular set thus created (taking into account various possible feature sets that form a tiered set) provides a measure of the sensitivity of the classification of all objects / patterns in X, as the set of features is gradually increased. Since the target set can be a proper subset of X, the sensitivity of the classification of objects / patterns can also be achieved with a variation of feature sets. Some quantitative measures of sensitivity could be easily defined.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions:
sections.text: Motivated by the practical problem of wireless sensor fusion, the author introduced the concept of "graduated quantity." Graduated characteristics show that an interesting phrase called "granular quantity" arises naturally in classification problems associated with an information system. Graduated target sets argue that the lower and upper approximations (of the target set) constitute a graded set of coarse quantities. Applications of "graduated" and granular quantities are actively explored.
